original_title: State Sector TUs go on sick leave; Education, Health, Transport not affected
original_body_lines: COLOMBO (News 1st); The Collective of State and Provincial State Services Trade Unions (CSPSSTU) resorted to a trade union action by applying for sick leave, on Tuesday (12).

Chandana Sooriyarachchi, the Convenor of the  Collective of State and Provincial State Services Trade Unions (CSPSSTU), speaking to News 1st, said that their primary demand is for a salary hike with a minimum raise of Rs. 20,000/-.
He also added that the government must reverse its decision to obtain 8% of the public sector employees' salaries as a contribution to the state.
Further, he called on the government to reinstate the pension scheme.

Chandana Sooriyarachchi said that trade unions attached to the school education sector, treatment services, hospital services, public transportation, aviation, and quarantine centers, among others were not included in the trade union action.
However, the trade union action is in effect across all ministries, departments, and divisional and regional secretariats, followed by protests at the respective locations.
At the same time, the nation-wide token strike by Postal Workers continued on Tuesday (12) as well, and it will come to an end at midnight.

Joint Convenor of the Joint Postal Workers Trade Union Alliance Chinthaka Bandara told News 1st that the token strike was launched over the weekend against the government's decision to sell the property of the Postal Department, including the Post Office buildings in Nuwara Eliya and Kandy.
In addition, they also demanded for a minimum monthly salary raise of Rs. 20,000/- from January 2024.
